Discussion at the Student
Council meeting held on Wednesday, March 18 centered around
issues raised at a rally held march
16 by the Coalition for a Free
South Africa.
Council President Mark
Komisky introduced the first
issue, the inclusion of
newspaper clippings in the files of
the University's Office of Student
Loans. Clippings detailing at least
one student's political protest activity were being kept in these
files.
Komisky had offered to call the
Financial Aid Office on Thursday, March 12 in order to ask
about the files. "I called the
Financial Aid Office on Thursday, and they really didn't know
what was going on," he said.
Coalition Liaison to Council
Tom Hall had erroneously stated
at the meeting on March 11 that
the files in question were being
kept by the University's Financial
Aid Office rather than the Office
of Student Loans.
An open memo to members of
the Hopkins community from
University Vice President for
Business Affairs John J. Lordan
was distributed. Lordan stated in
the,letter that "upon reviewing
the practices of the Office of Student Loans. . . , I have instructed
the office to remove all news clippings from student loan files, and
to no longer collect or maintain
news clippings on student borrowers. The original purpose was
to compile information that would
be of use in locating students—as
loan recipients—in the event that
ever became necessary.
Lordan added in the memo that
"extracurricular activites of
students have never had any bearing on a student's ability to obtain loans and/or scholarship
funds at the Johns Hopkins
University. Any previous information on extracurricular activities compiled by the Office of
Student loans or elsewhere in the
University will be disposed of and
will have no bearing on financially related matters.
A Coalition press release,
which was also distributed at the
meeting, said that the group "will
be meeting with President Muller
in the next few days to ensure that
this file-keeping does not ever occur again . . .."
The next issue Council discused was a complaint from

Buildings and Grounds Chairman
Jim Finnerty about an incident
which occured at the March 16
rally.
According to Finnerty, Scott
Lippe, a-member of the College
Republicans, "provoked one of
the [Coalition] protestors" during
a counterdemonstration organized by the College Republicans.
Hall, another witness, supported
Finnerty's claims. Finnerty said
that Lippe threatened the protestors at one point.
Not wishing to condemn the
entire organization. Finnerty
suggested that Council pass a
resolution condemning Lippe's
conduct.
Senior Class Representative
Brad Marks opposed this idea.
"It's ridiculous for us to deal with
this," he said. "There should be
a board to deal with [censure of
the actions of individual
students]. We really can't."
Several other Council members
remarked that passage of the type
of resolution requested without
hearing testimony from Lippe
would be improper.
Sophomore Class Representative Susan Land suggested that
discussion be tabled while she and
any other members interested
prepared "a memo to the
Hopkins community." She said
this would prevent Council from
covering the same ground again
at the next meeting.
Land, Hall and others made
various suggestions to the effect
that there should be a limit where
freedom of expression becomes
disruption and should no longer
be permitted on campus.
A variety of issues were also
brought up at Wednesday's Student Council meeting.
Council president-elect Scott
FitzGerald announced that the
Hopkins Shelter Project will continue to function at least until the
end of April. The organization is
composed of student volunteers
who work at a shelter for the
homeless at 2213 Greenmount
Avenue.
An emergency grant from the
city has extended the shelter's
operation, which was to cease on
March 31, and there is a possibility of federal aid after that point,
said FitzGerald.
According to FitzGerald,
"There is a lot of administration
support" for the project, and
there is a possibility that the
group will be made an ongoing
enterprise along the lines of

freshman orientation.
Sophomore Class representative Jonathon Hubbard and FitzGerald both recommended the
project to anyone who might be
interested in participating. Security shuttle van service or student
automobile transportation is
available for both shifts, 6 to 11
p.m. and 11 p.m. to 7a.m.
Interested students can
volunteer to work either shift by
signing up on a list on the door
of the SC office in Levering Hall,
or can call Chris Weininger at
889-8550 for more information,
said FitzGerald.
Senior Class Vice President
Paul Kadri announced that
Hollander Dorm will be attempting to break the world record for
marathon volleyball by playing
for eighty-seven hours. According to Kadri, the Guinness Book
of World Records' value for
longest such game ever played is
now eighty-four hours.
The game will begin at 9 a.m.
on Sunday, April 12 and the
original twelve players in the
game will need to continue
without substitutions in order for
the record to be valid. Players can
drop out without endangering the
attempt "as long as good
volleyball is being played," said
Kadri.
Also at the two meetings:
*The results of a Student council survey on the subject of
student-run radio at Hopkins
were announced. Students'
answers to the question,"Do you
support a student-run radio station?" averaged between 4.7 and
4.8 on a scale of one to five, with
five indicating most support for
the idea. Approximately half the
students responding were
freshmen.
*Freshmen Class Representative George Lerner reported
that the freshman class plans to
hold an outdoor concert this
spring, although plans are still
tentative and no decision has been
made as to the band.
*Coalition for a Free South
Africa member Bijoy Mathew announced plans by the Coalition to
put forth a binding referendum on
campus in cooperation with
Seiler's to determine whether
Pepsi will replace Coca-Cola in
campus machines and cafeterias.
According to Mathew, Coca-Cola
continues to profit from apartheid although it claims to have
withdrawn from South Africa last
year.

Sex in Advertising Considered
At Wednesday Noon Series
by Kerry Tesoriero
Professor Mark Crispin Miller,
head of Film Studies in the
Writing Seminars department,
presented a lecture entitled
"Light my Lucky—The Myth of
Sex in Advertising" last
Wednesday.
His argument stated that sex is
not at the root of today's advertisments, contrary to popular
belief. The ideal notion of sex, in
Professor Miller's opinion, is actually missing from magazine ads
and television commercials.
Miller supplemented his thesis
with several slides of contemporary advertisements. In each
example he presented, the product to be sold acted as a physical
barrier preventing interaction.
One ad showed a women's ringcovered hand shielding her lips
from the man who hovered over
her. A bottle of liquor stood
directly between the faces of a
couple shown in another
example.

Advertising depends upon the
consumer's dissatisfaction, according to Miller. A salesperson
wants to present his product as
the solution to problems, a form
of protection, or a source of
Advertisements
strength.
therefore depict sex as a
dangerous prospect and the product as a type of defense.
A particular ad demonstrated
the truth in Miller's theory quite
blatantly. It featured a pair of
catlike female eyes in the rearview mirror of a car, the product
in this case. An attractive male
stood beyond the car, on the roadside. The caption beneath the picture read, "If you're not the
predator, you're the prey."
Miller explained that as late as
the seventies, most ads were
outrageously sexist, whereas
many of today's ads are actually
geared toward flattering the
woman by giving her the physical

position of superiority.
Sexism still abounds in society, said Miller, but advertisers attempt to give the woman a false
sense that a particular product
will somehow give her the upper
hand. Ads depict men in
vulnerable, defenseless positions.
At times a man is shown at the
mercy of a woman who holds her
hands around his unguarded
neck.
Auression is at the root of
modern sales techniques in
Miller's view. Whether an ad
favors the male's or female's
possession of power depends
upon who the intended buyer is.
In either case, one figure will
always Nupercede another. Never
does an advertisement depict
males and females as equals. The
struggle between them for power
is exploited and the product's
capacity to resolve that struggle
is suggested.

Effective March
23, Eugene S. Sunshine, former
New York State Treasurer, nas
ben appointed treasurer of the
Johns Hopkins University.
Before being named deputy
commissioner for tax policy
analysis of the New York State
Department of Taxation and
Finance, Sunshine served as State
Treasurer from August 1982 until January 1986. Additionally he
has served as a member of the
governing boards of several New
York State financing agencies that
provided bond financing for
housing, health care, and educational facilities, he has also performed various financial roles for
fifteen other state agencies, including the teachers' retirement
system and the state insurance
fund.
From December 1977 to july
1982, Sunshine was director of
energy conservation for the New
York State Energy Office, administering a multi-million dollar
energy-conservation grant program, which benefitted many colleges and universities in New
York. In 1982, he received the
Alfred E. Smith Award from the
American Society for Public Administration for outstanding
achievement in implementing the
New York State energy conservation programs.
"We are very fortunate indeed
that we will benefit from the
wealth of experienct that Mr.
Sunshine will bring to the financial management of the University," said Bowie, in announcing

In his new position at Johns
Hopkins, Sunshine will take
responsibility for all the corporate
treasury functions, including
oversight of the endowment investment program. He will also
serve as secretary to the Investment Committee of the University's Board of Trustees.

The Financial File Fiasco
by Paul Genest

Shortly before the publication of our
last issue, we were shocked to learn that
the Office of Student Loans had been
amassing photocopied newspaper clippings concerning the political activities
of certain students. The story broke
when Jessica Reed, a member of the
Coalition for a Free South Africa who
was arrested in the shanty protest of
September 29, noticed Baltimore Sun
clippings in her file several weeks ago.
On March 12, the News-Letter was
able to verify the existence of the clippings, and on March 16, the Coalition
staged a rally which, among other
things, was intended to protest the
presence of extraneous information in
students' financial aid files.
The same day, Vice President of
Business Affairs John J. Lordan announced his decision to purge all financial files of information on "extracurricular activities." In addition, a statement issued by the University that day
emphasized the fact that students have
the legal right to review their files in the
Office of Student Loans.
We applaud Lordan's announcement
and the speed with which it was made.
Decisions concerning the distribution
of financial aid ought to be made

without regard to a recipient's political
beliefs or activities. Certainly then, the
removal of information about those
beliefs and activities is a wise step. It
safeguards students from unfair treatment and enhances the University's image as an institution where the exchange
of opinions is prized.
In recent weeks, certain groups have
suggested that the presence of the
newspaper clippings in financial files
may have been part of a scheme to prevent some students from receiving the
funds necessary for their educations.
But after the events on March 16, we
tend to doubt that explanation.
The candor shown by the Administration in acknowledging the existence of
the materials, the speed with which the
issue was resolved, and the steps taken
to eliminate the threat of. financial
recriminations on politically active
students all suggest that the University
is indeed interested in fair play in its
distribution of financial aid (and probably always has been).
We are pleased with the administration's response to the financial file
fiasco and we hope to see such prudence
in the administration's dealings with
students continue.

Fair Coverage
To the Editor:
The recent coverage of particular events on campus has led
to doubts concerning whether the
News-Letter is committed to
reporting objectively on political
issues at Hopkins. A bias towards
conservative beliefs and groups
seems to be evident in its use of
selective coverage of events and
its refusal to report pertinent
evidence concerning the defacing
of fliers of campus organizations.
In early March, the Hopkins
Latin American Action Group ran
a series of events to focus attention on different controversies in
the region. Various events were
co-sponsored with the Chaplain's
Office, Young Democrats and the
class on Non-violence. The series
included women from Nicaragua;
the president of the University
assembly of El Salvador;
speakers on the Latin American
debt crisis; an exiled student from
El Salvador; and a drama on
Guatamalan refugees.
After the completion of the
series, we were disturbed to
discover that only the U.S.
military spokesman had been
covered. No mention had been
made at all of the other events.
We feel that to cover only the
most conservative speaker, one
whose views are reflected daily in
the mainstream media, shows an

inclination away from publishing
the voices of those who are
generally not heard. It further
reflects a decision to present only certain political opinions, while
ignoring others not as widely
accepted.
Jon Stempel, one of the news
editors, stated that [the NewsLetter] chose to cover the
American military viewpoint
because it was the most interesting part of the series. We
wonder why he did not consider
worthy the first-hand experiences
of Latin Americans? Was it really necessary to further expound
upon the arguments given daily
for U.S. intervention in the
region? We hope that an attempt
will be made in the future to be
more even-handed in covering
political issues, especially when
a number of sides are presented.
We are also concerned about
another aspect of the coverage of
recent events by the News-Letter.
The last issue reported how our
fliers and those of other groups
had been defaced by stamps

stamps.

direct participation, but agreed it
was a "cute" idea.

didn't have control over what CR
members did, so if some of them
had participated he shouldn't be
held responsible.
Braswell stated that the stamps
had been utilized to irritate our
group, and he was pleased to see
that it had accomplished this task
because of our obvious concern.
He defended their use with,
"Wouldn't the KGB approve?"
Incidentally, since we addressed
Mr. Citardi, no new instances of
defacement of our fliers have
been noticed.

been much discussion about the
inevitable disruption of the
University's second most popular
major, I would like to appeal to
the Academic Council, not as an
IS major, but rather as a student
who has been fortunate enough to
have been in one of Dr. David's
classes.
This appeal is being made on
behalf of all of those students,
namely our freshmen and future
Hopkins students, who have not
yet had such an opportunity.
Surely, Dr. David's abilities in
lecture hall are not being called
into question; yet, it is this area
that I would like to emphasize.
Dr. David manages to provide
for his students a stimulating fifty minutes of examination of the
international system. Drawing
ideas from the most reputable
sources, combining them with his
own theories (a reputable source
in itself) and presenting them in
an organized and coherent
fashion, Dr. David succeeds, in
each lecture, in provoking his
students to apply their own
analysis and viewpoint to each
topic.
His ability to link history with
current world affairs is a valuable
aspect of his survey courses. The
occasional wit that he adds to his
lectures is always timely, entertaining, and educating, as it invariably serves to convey an important point. The readings required of the students reflect the
nature of the lectures: they are
relevant, interesting, and
thought-provoking.
The high attendance of his lectures is indicative of the enthusiasm that he is able to maintain for his course. How often can
it be said of a lecture, that the majority of its students look forward
to attending it? Such a statement
is true of Dr. David's lectures.

the IS department one of the best
in the nation has been previously
noted, as have his numerous
research accomplishments. Attention should also be focused on
his abilities as a professor, on his
abilities to directly educate the
students in a specific area. Should
that not be the primary duty of a
professor?
Dr. David has clearly gone
beyond fulfilling that duty, as he

has the other requirements which
this University places before him.
Not only does he serve this institution as a whole, he serves the
students

On 16 March 1987, a variety
of Hopkins students and other individuals gathered on the steps of
Gilman Hall to voice discontent
with CIA interviews on-campus
as well as University tampering
with student loan files. This
demonstration was met be a
counterdemonstration involving
other Hopkins' students.
Unarguably, it is the right of
these groups to express their opinion. Yet, one member of the
counterdemonstration proceeded
to needlessly provoke another individual of the anti-CIA group in
order to provide cause for the termination of the initial gathering.
I witnessed the subsequent ruckus
as the "assaulted" student proceeded to file charges with the
Baltimore City Police.
The placement of material pertaining to student political activities in loan files is a very
serious allegation which merits
concern. Although I do not support the Coalition's argument to
prohibit the CIA from recruiting
on-campus or their views on the
CIA. I very much support their
right to freely express these
views. James Madison posited that the
right to criticize "public
characters and measures" is the
heart of American freedom.
Granted, certain expressions must
be limited in some circumstances
by the weight of greater interests.
This balancing of interests,
however, should not be taken
lightly.
In this sense, the suppression of
dissent contradicts the ideals upon
which this nation was founded as
well as the ideals which I desire
to serve in the Foreign Service.
The suppression of opinions—no
matter how disagreeable or
repulsive—tramples the sentiments espoused in the Declaration of Independence as well as
the Constitution and its Bill of
Rights and repeatedly reaffirmed
in countless other documents and
actions. Democracy rests upon
this diffusion and integration of
diverse notions. Self-appointed
"mindguards"--and their unquestioned acceptance—cause
democratic ideals to wither. This
is especially true in a university
environment in which one purpose of education is to acquire the
tools to critically digest information and then make informed
decisions; that is, an independent
critical spirit.
The use of tactics solely designed to provoke response and thus
curb dissent is deplorable. It
bodes ill for the United States if
the next generation of citizens
cannot rationally discuss opposing ideologies as well as accept
the right to hold and express such
viewpoints rather than hurl personal insults and obscenities or
threaten to "drop bookbags" and
teach lessons to "pansies— (These
words are not mine).
I hold no illusions you will
change, Mr. Lippe, but you
represent that which I abhor—
intelligence constricted by a
closed-mind.
Jim Finnerty

At present, according to

the University, except the School
of Hygiene and Public Health.
In Canada next week, administrators at the University of
Waterloo will vote on just such a
policy.

areas to be decided by management board."

laboratories, University vehicles,
shared work spaces, offices and
lounges that open onto work
areas,
spaces, reception
restrooms, seminar, conference,
and other meeting rooms."

smokers.

offices. Students may not smoke

considered opinions from anyone
interested, but responses came
primarily from faculty and staff,
with a few student contributions.

who chaired the committee, said
that "most of the response" had
been in favour of a stricter policy.
The University of Waterloo
maintained a smoking policy
since 1967, but it was not revised until August, 1980. The present proposal is the first of its

now in effect, "Smoking areas
may include some coffee,
cafeteria and lounge areas, as
determined by the approp-"Ite

The Flip Side: Where to, U2?
by Phil Gochenour
If you're a child of the 80's and
you haven't heard of U2, you
must've spent your adolescence
in a cave somewhere for the
cultural equivalent thereof. More
likely, however, you have at least
one or two memories for which
U2 is providing the background
music. For me, it's memories of
hot, Tennesee-Williams-Southern
nights spent in abandoned parking lots, with U2's War blaring
out from half-a-dozen car stereos,
providing the stimulus for expressions of adolescent (and some

post-adolescent) angst.
War was the album that
brought U2 to everyone's attention. But before War, there was
Boy (1980), produced by Steve
Lillywhite. U2's first album, it
established them as part of a new
wave of anthem rockers with a
stripped-down, bare-bones
sound. It was the natural
predecessor for War, an album
known for such anthemic songs as
"New Year's Day" and "Sunday, Bloody Sunday." Thus,
with these two albums, it would
seem as if U2 became a definable
entity.

There was another side to U2,
one that was glimpsed on the
album October (1981). Although
still bearing the earmarks of being a Steve Lillywhite production, songs such as "Tomorrow"
and "October" revealed a more
spiritual, sensitive side to U2. In
1984, everyone was anxiously
awaiting the new album to see
how this schizophrenic split
would be resolved. The album
was The Unforgettable Fire, and
it was an even further departure
from the sound of War and Boy
than October had been. The
group dumped Steve Lillywhite

as producer, and picked up the
production team of Eno/Lanois.
The Eno/Lanois team brought
with them a new production
philosophy and a more layered,
processed sound. Keying in on
the expressiveness and range of
Bono's voice, and the clean,
spare sound of the Edge's guitar,
The Unforgettable Fire had the
qualities of a new-wave spiritual.
Fans of the earlier U2 gaped and
wondered what was next—will
that old raw edge of intensity ever
be back?

Durang's Crisp Satire
by Rich Bigelow
Christopher Durang belongs to
a long tradition of playwrights
who use black comedy as a vehicle for social criticism. The current Center Stage production of
The Marriage of Bette and Boo,
which runs through April 12, offers audiences ample opportunity to laugh and squirm. Like those
of his predecessor G.B. Shaw,
Durang's wittiest and truest insights rise out of the hypocrisy
and illusions which organized
religion creates in family life. The
difference is that Durang is a
Catholic Baby Boomer, and the
references he makes to movies
and holidays and the feminine
mystique place his characters and
situations squarely within our experience. His humor is often
blunt and savagely effective. One
scene in the Center Stage production in which a fat priest imitates
frying bacon brought the house
down. The combination of
slapstick, naturalistic dialogue,
and grotesque plot turn the play
into a sort of nightmarish Freudian farce.
The Marriage ofBette and Boo
unfolds as a series of recollections
from the youth of the narrator, an
English Lit. grad student named
Matt Hudlocke (Miles Chaplin).
The play opens with all of the
characters except Matt standing
on a wedding-cake-shaped platform singing a nice, Catholicsounding benediction. Matt
emerges to the side of the stage
and informs the audience that
"just as dreams must be put in
order and perspective in order to
understand them, so must the
endless details of waking life be
ordered and then carefully considered." Bette and Boo are
Matt's parents, and by introducing us to the wedding party he exposes the tragicomic world of his
youth to inspection. The bridal

party is a particularly scary
group. Bette Brennan (Linda
Cook), the bride, a chatty A.A.
Milne reader marrying on the rebound from an unconsummated
affair, has one goal in life: procreation. She has two sisters,
Joan (Alison Bevan), a sharptongued tart whose unfaithful
Greek husband has become a
family joke, and Emily (Mary
Catherine Wright), a sensitive, a
terribly, terribly guilty Catholic
who winds up institutionalized
after failing to become a nun.
These three are dominated by
their mother, Margaret (Theresa
Hughes), a woman who would
rather have her children fail and
live at home than leave the maternal nest. She is seconded in these
efforts by the father of the family, Paul Brennan (Jerry Mayer),
a character who mutters not one
intelligible word in his time on
stage. The groom's party is an
even more sordid assortment of
characters. The groom, Boo
Hudlocke (Stephen Mendillo), a
quiet, thirtyish, thoughtless hunk,
drinks too much. This is a natural
reaction to his father, Karl (John
Carpenter), a viciously foulmouthed misogynist who entertains himself by reminding his
wife Soot (Trinity Thompson)
how stupid she is. The wedding
is performed by a sardonic priest
(I.M. Hobson), and the tale of
marital woe begins.
Characters like the Brennans
and Hudlockes seem more appropriate in soap operas than in
comedies. Part of Durang's talent
as a playwright stems from his
ability to transform their own
sense of seriousness in absurdist
humor. Matt relates the various
episodes which lead to his
parents' divorce in the context of
his own schoolwork, particularly the essays which he always
seems to be writing about
Thomas Hardy. One scene

presents Matt defending a thesis
that Eustacia Vye in The Return
of the Native is neurotic because
her environment forces her to be;
the next scene shows Matt testifying to his father's alcoholism in
divorce court. The disparity between the almost maudlin crises in
his family life and the dignified,
rational analysis he applies to the
lives of the characters in the
novels he studies provides much
comic material. His attitude
towards the Catholic Church
stems as much from the unwillingness of his family to question
harmful doctrines as it does from
the unconcern and irrelevance of
the parish priest. Bette wants to
have lots of children; she and Boo
have the wrong blood type. Bette
gets pregnant, the child dies,
Bette wants another child, Boo
turns to drink. The two logical
solutions to the problem are rejected by the couple for religious
reasons: Boo asks Bette to stop
having kids, but Bette refuses
because she sees no reason why
God can't grant her a miracle and
allow another child to live the
way Matt did. Bette goes through
five pregnancies and four
stillbirths. The couple rejects
divorce until after the fifth
pregnancy because it is against
Catholic doctrine. The whole
family goes on a marriage retreat
at one point, to be told by the
priest that he cannot do anything
for them because "A husband and
wife are stuck together." The
play is punctuated by scenes in
the hospital waiting room when
the various stillborn blue or pink
bundles are thrown on the stage
and everyone has to decide what
to do with them. Matt sees things
in a grotesque light, yet his world
is both humorous and poignant.
The Center Stage production
holds up to the challenge to be
both very funny and retain the
sense of familiarity Durang's

situations evoke from the audience. Director Richard Hamburger elicits crisp, substantial
performancesfrom everyone in
his tight professional ensemble.
Special mention should be made
of Linda Cook's performance as
Bette, a role which demands both
emotional virtuosity and an ability
to play stupid well. The set design
and musical score enhance the
macabre effect of the humor by
placing the actors' naturalistic
character studies in the context of
a cartoon-like world, with a set
and sounds that belong on a
"Peanuts" T.V. special. The expressionistic production values
set well with the kind of quirky
narrative Durang uses, somewhat
reminiscent of Tennessee
Williams.
The more obvious Williams
parallel, Matt's role as a narrator

in a memory play, raises the
question of the relationship between comedy and drama. The
gross quality of the lives of
Durang's characters as viewed in
retrospect by Matt turn the play
into a sort of parody of The Glass
Menagerie. Because the play does
not appear to take itself seriously. Durang is able to take aim at
the cynicism, passivity, and
credulity of modern life in a way

Johns Hopkins (3-2) has just
strolled past the halfway mark of
their lacrosse regular season, but
in the words of Coach Don Zimmerman, "We haven't proven
anything yet."
After two superb games in
which Hopkins dominated each
quarter, Zimmerman was upset
by a talented Virginia squad. The
games against Washington College and Princeton were convincing exhibitions for th! Jays, but
the contests were not real tests for
Hopkins.
This season it appears that
Princeton will have a tough time
improving on their win production of last year, a lone victory.
And Division III Washington is
not the Hobart power that managed a Syracuse upset last year.
A peculiar event happened to
the pesky Jays against Virginia.
Even more unusual than a loss on
Hopkins' magic carpet was the
shocking final score, 9-7. The
Cavaliers won by two goals.
Entering the Virginia contest,
the Zimmerman dynasty had a
grand total of four losses (with 40
wins) spanning four seasons but
had never lost a decision by more
than one score.
Zimmerman labelled the loss to
Virginia "a team effort" and
added, "They all played poorly.
We're still trying to play our best
lacrosse."
The Blue Jays, however, are
not panicking yet. With the expanded NCAA lacrosse tournament field now set at twelve,
Hopkins would most likely struggle into the tournament with a
.500 record, using their strength
of schedule as a crutch.
It wouldn't be surprising if all
of the 1987 Blue Jays Division I
opponents except Princeton make
the tournament.
Hopkins will not have another
easy game this season and must
face North Carolina, Army,
Maryland, Navy, and Towson

HOPKINS 23, WASHINGTON
7
Tue., March 17
Johns Hopkins sprinted to a 3-0
lead before Washington College
could gain control of the ball, and
the Blue Jays went on to run away
with a 23-7 decision before nearly 2,000 at Homewood Field.
Greg Kelly controlled the opening faceoff, and Mike Morrill fed
John Dressel for a backhand
score from five yards away to
give the Jays a 1-0 advantage at
the 44-second mark.
Bruce Chanenchuk won the ensuing faceoff, and Pat Russell
assisted on Larry Ledoyen's blast
for a 2-0 edge at 1:48.
Chanenchuk gobbled up
another draw, and Morrill passed the ball to Craig Bubier, who
scored the first of his five goals
for a 3-0 lead with only two
minutes gone.
"We wanted to come out explosively, and the guys responded," said the satisfied Hopkins
coach, Don Zimmerman. "From
looking over our first two games,
we saw that we had started slowly and that got us in trouble. We
had to play catch-up. We wanted
to correct this. We were all over
the groundballs early, and it sure
helped our offense."
Hopkins, displaying a ?hi]
Simms-like passing attack
quick ball movement, tallied five
more goals in the first quarter for
an 8-0 lead.
The scoring festivities continued for Hopkins in the second
period, as Hopkins wreaked
havoc on the Washington defense
with a tremendous groundball effort and an explosive fast break
tempo.
The score rose to 12-0 before
the Shoremen could manage their
first goal at 10:48 of the second
quarter, when 5'6", 155 lb.
Chris Dollar sent a sharp angled
shot past Hopkins goalie Stuart
Jones,
The Blue Jays blazed an incredible 42 of their 61 shots on
goal. The Jays enjoyed this success despite occasional questionable shot selection. The lopsided score may have had some
influence on shot creativity. The
Jays had a couple of forty-yard
shots at a vacated Washington
net. 6'5", 210 lb. defenseman
Steve Mitchell missed a goal,
having difficulty choking up on
his long stick, after leading a fast
break.
The Jays were certainly not
aiming for second base; however,
a Shoreman scorcher missed the
net and found Willie "The Rock"
Raedle playing the infield for the
Hopkins batmen.
"We didn't react well in the
beginning, and Hopkins took ad-

vantage of it," said the NCAA
Div. III runner-up coach, Terry
Corcoran. "We're a young, inexperienced team and that showed today. We didn't do the job in
the broken situations. It seemed
like Hopkins always had someone
open. They killed us with their
transition game. Also Hopkins
controlled the groundballs, and
we never seemed to have the ball
in the first half."
"We're not a very strong team
right now, but we have a lot of
kids who won't quit. And if they
won't quit, I surely won't. We
didn't do the job on defense, and
our offense did not play well. We
didn't execute properly."
Attackman Bubier notched five
scores and an assist to lead the
Hopkins offensive attack.
LeDoyen had three goals and two
assists, Brendan Kelly contributed three goals (that included an underhand riser) and two
assists, and John Ciccarone contributed two goals and three
assists. Dressel, Scott Marr and
Jay Clarke netted two sizzlers
each, and Morrill and Russell had
4 assists apiece.
HOPKINS 21, PRINCETON 6
Sat., March 21
Unleashing a blistering offensive attack, Johns Hopkins tamed the Princeton Tigers, 21-6,
before 6,500 at Homewood Field.
The mighty Blue Jays, who put
on a passing and stickwork clinic,
won their third consecutive game,
building a 10-3 halftime lead.
Hopkins outshot the Ivy League
felines, 60-32, and won 20 of the
31 faceoffs.
"Hopkins has so much talent,"
said Princeton coach Jerry
Schmidt, a former All-America
attackman with the Jays. "They
move the ball so well, especially
inside, it was like they were on
extra-man all afternoon."
The Blue Jays put 38 of its 60
shots on goal, hit the post with
four other rockets and scored
three extra-man goals in six opportunities. John Wright, the
sophomore Tiger goalie, was
outstanding in the goal, making
17 saves. He, perhaps, saved the
rambunctious Hopkins band from
performing a concert.
The Hopkins defense was so
strong that it did not commit a
foul for the first 44 minutes and
12 seconds, allowed only one
extra-man score, and continually
checked the ball out of the black
and blued Princeton players'
sticks.
Once again, Hopkins bolted out
of the starting blocks and captured a 4-0 lead. The Jays never
looked back.
Greg Kelly started the scoring
action by bouncing in a goal, using an assist from John Ciccarone
at 1:17. Craig Bubier found a
missed shot behind the left side of
the Princeton net and delivered it
for a tally from 5 yards away with
2:11 gone in the contest.
Ciccarone made it 3-0, when
he bounced in a goal from the
right side off a Brendan Kelly
pass at 6:12.
Bubier gave an assist to Scott
Marr, as Bubier's blast found the
net again at the 9:55 mark of the
sprint for a 4-0 advantage. "I was
generally pleased with our efContinued on Page 25

The Jays were beaten on
groundballs and faceoffs. Then
the Jays were beaten on the
scoreboard on their home turf
before a near-sellout crowd of
6,000.
"I still don't know why we
played so poorly today," said
coach Don Zimmerman, shaking
his head in disgust. "We just
weren't ready to play the game.
Our timing was off, and we didn't
hustle."
The Cavaliers held a 53-41
edge in groundballs, which simply means they outhustled the Blue
Jays. Virginia had not beaten
Johns Hopkins since 1980, 12-9,
and had not won at Homewood
Field since 1971, 9-8.
The Blue Jays were out of sync
offensively and several times
missed cutters for potential goals.
Early in the third period Mike
Morrill collided with teammate
Dave Pietramala at midfield. And
no one was even checking them.
The Cavaliers' freshman
goaltender Stew Ridgley from St.
Paul's School added to the Jays'
frustration and finished with 16
saves. Virginia fans did not notice
the absence of injured Peter
Sheehan, the nation's best goalie
in 1986.
"Lacrosse is a game of hustling, and the team that gobbles up
those loose balls usually wins,"
said Zimmerman."We kept giving them second and third opportunities, and you can't give a team
the caliber of Virginia that many
chances. When you have five or
six people standing around on offense at one time, it cuts down on
your scoring opportunities. We
should be doubling what we
scored today. I'm extremely
disappointed in our offense."

deficit in the standings. And even

rays. What else is there? Signup

endeavor is a success, floor

interview.

Being an ace reporter and avid
"Weekly World News" reader,
I decided to stake out the socalled "possessed" shanty one
dark and stormy evening.
By midnight, nothing very exciting had happened. Flies had
made several attempts to swarm
around the ruins, but they simply got stuck in the black goo
covering the splintered boards
and died. This journalist was not
impressed.
An hour or so later the black

goo began to move and take
shape. A blinding light appeared
from within its depths and when
my eyes recovered, I could not
believe what I saw.
Standing before me was Pat Sajak and his ever present, ever
smiling, ever synthetic sidekick
Vanna White. Apparently the
ruins had been converted into a
studio for a game show called
"The Cause of the Week." I admit it, I was frankly curious as to
what was going on.
After a commercial break for
Holy Water Repellant, the show's
contestants appeared and introduced themselves. Liberace was the
first to materialize out of the most
and my, what an entrance. Sporting a paisley tuxedo, sequined
tiger skin cape, and two foot tall
diamond tiara.
He bounced to his microphone

and said, "Hello there. I represent all tacky, overdressed,
lounge Piano Players. We want
the right to wear all the polyester
and rhinestone we can. After all,
our motto is, "Even if you don't
have it, flaunt it!" with a thrust
of the hips and a blinding smile
Vanna signalled the audience to
applause.
As the clapping and yelling
died down, a silver string came
down from the clouds and
deposited Shirley Maclaine
behind her microphone. "My
name today is Shirley Maclaine,
but I have also been called Queen
of Atlantis, Mortimer the Great.
Jean Nolans, and in my most
previous life, Ira Remsen,
chemistry professor."
I'm here today to ask to be
allowed to live as many lives as
I want to and to exist in as many

dimensions as I can. Three of my
ten dimensions were flown in on
a UFO at the Academy Awards
while the other seven basked in
luxury at a Peruvian hot spring.
I therefore also ask for equality
among my dimensions; those
poor three should not have suffered so."
With a plunging neckline that
was almost at waistline, Vanna
bent over to turn on not only half
the males in the audience but also
a tapedeck to introduce the final
contestant.
With "Jailhouse rock" blaring
in the background a rather portly
Elvis waddled into his position.
He said, "Uh, hello, um,I would
like to, uh, win the right to drink,
eat, and inject drugs into myself
until I'm silly. After all, I'm
dead, so, uh, why don't we
loosen up the reins a bit, huh?"

It was obvious to me that
Shirley was going to win and in
the end she did. How could someone with a ten dimensional
personality lose?
By 4, it was over. Shirley was
reeled in on her string to join
herself in far away cosmos. Elvis
paddled off stage but only after
catching a bell bottom on the
wheel of Causes and being
catapulted across the stage.
Liberace rode off stage in a
golden chariot, a showman to the
end.
Pat and Vanna returned to their
natural state, the charming black
slime and as the last of the sludge
receded back under the shanty, I
knew it was all true. The rumors,
the stories, all of it was true,
because here in Baltimore, there
resides the Shantyville Horror.

Campaign Chairman Morris
W. Offit has announced a $50
million donation to the Campaign
for Johns Hopkins with a
restricted gift to the athletic
department. When pressed for
details, Athletic Director Robert
M. Scott said sullenly, "I don't
wish to comment, but I will say
something. If this gift is accepted,
it will be a sad day for the fine
lacrosse tradition we've had here
at JHU."
Scott's anxiety can only stem
from NCAA Proposition 106,
which puts an end to multidivisional classification in athletics,
in effect forcing Hopkins to skip
up to Division I in all sports to
keep Division I status in lacrosse.
"I was all set to drop football,"
Scott said in an interview. "But
then he came along 'flashing all
that money. I fired the head football coach so we could fully concentrate on lacrosse. Football
hasn't become a consistent winner here at Hopkins — it was losing money, and I thought no one
would mind if I finally got rid of
it.
"But then he came along, "he
continued, "and now my precious
lacrosse and my job are both
down the toilet."
Who is he? Why, Kevin
Thomas Tully, of course.
Hopkins fans remember the
glory years of Blue Jay football
when All-American Kevin
Thomas Tully terrorized opponents with his relentless style

of play. I myself shed a tear when
they retired old number 95 last
fall. I thought that would he the
last we'd see of KIT. He was to
graduate, finally, and then head
off to Harvard Medical School,
which of course is now taking
over Johns Hopkins Medical
School, to begin a successful
career in medicine.
Until he heard of Bob Scott's
evil plan.
"I was sitting in Orgo the other
day. correcting the professor for
a mistake he had made in his lecture, when Adam Warner rushed into class and told me the
news, "said Kevin Thomas Tully. "1 was devastated. What
could 1 do, I thought? I felt
helpless. Until I went home and
opened my mail. I opened a
brown envelope marked 'Urgent'
and found that I was the first $50
million winner in the Publisher's
Clearing House Sweepstakes!
Thank you Ed McMahon! Right
then, I knew what I had to do.
"I called up Morris Offit and
Bob Scott,"said Kevin Thomas
Tully, "and well, basically
Howard, I bought myself the
athletic department and appointed
myself athletic director and head
football coach."
Kevin Thomas Tully promised
a football program at Hopkins
that would make the SMU program "look like a bunch of fairies
and choir boys." His plans include the construction of a $250
million, 100,000 seat domed
stadium — yes, the Kevin
Thomas Tullydome — on the pre-

sent site of Homewood Field.
"I don't care if Governor
Schaefer wanted to build two
stadiums in Camden Yards, "
said Kevin Thomas Tully. "I'm
building the Tullydome here at
Hopkins. Homewood Field is a
dump — it's too small and doesn't
have luxury sky boxes. That's
where the money is — in those
sky boxes.
"As far as lacrosse is concerned, " he continued, "they
can play on the BIA fields for all
that I care. But. I'll tell you one
thing — if I see any of those guys
within 100 yards of my dome,
they'll be shot. The Tullydome is
for football ONLY! I'm going to
make this school a football
factory!
Sources close to Hopkins indicate that Kevin Thomas Tully
will indeed succeed in his plans.
He has already appointed another
former Hopkins football great,
Steve "Gyro" Paradakis, to head
the admissions office "to make
sure we get some good players in
and some good looking girls for
cheerleaders." When asked how
he could do this, Kevin Thomas
Tully replied, "Money talks,
Howard."
The ceremonial groundbreaking took place on April 1 on
the 50-yard line of what is
presently Homewood Field.
University President Steven
Muller was in attendance and
when told that construction would
interfere with the remaining two
home lacrosse games and
Homecoming, he echoed Kevin

Thomas Tully's sentiments.
"Frankly Howard," he said,
"this is what's best for the
University. Lacrosse is a fag
sport anyway. Who cares? Football is what makes the big bucks
and keeps me in the Bahamas
with these fancy threads and this
great tan."
Construction is scheduled to be
completed by September I in time
for the home opener versus
defending national champion
Penn State. Kevin Thomas Tully's home schedule also includes
Miami, Nebraska, Oklahoma,
and USC. Away games are
scheduled versus Florida State,
Hawaii, UCLA, BYU, and
Yeshiva University. The last two

are expected to be especially
difficult.
Kevin Thomas Tully has set his
salary at $1 million per year and
said. "My players will receive at
least half that much."
It is this reporter's professional
opinion that Johns Hopkins
University, under the guidance of
football mastermind Kevin
Thomas Tully, will be contenders
for the national championship in
its first year of operation. Their
facilities will be the finest, and
their athletes will be the highest
paid. This is Howard Cosell,
writing about my favorite, most
personally idolized university and
institution of higher learning.

Discussion at the Student
Council meeting held on Wednesday, March 18 centered around
issues raised at a rally held march
16 by the Coalition for a Free
South Africa.
Council President Mark
Komisky introduced the first
issue, the inclusion of
newspaper clippings in the files of
the University's Office of Student
Loans. Clippings detailing at least
one student's political protest activity were being kept in these
files.
Komisky had offered to call the
Financial Aid Office on Thursday, March 12 in order to ask
about the files. "I called the
Financial Aid Office on Thursday, and they really didn't know
what was going on," he said.
Coalition Liaison to Council
Tom Hall had erroneously stated
at the meeting on March 11 that
the files in question were being
kept by the University's Financial
Aid Office rather than the Office
of Student Loans.
An open memo to members of
the Hopkins community from
University Vice President for
Business Affairs John J. Lordan
was distributed. Lordan stated in
the,letter that "upon reviewing
the practices of the Office of Student Loans. . . , I have instructed
the office to remove all news clippings from student loan files, and
to no longer collect or maintain
news clippings on student borrowers. The original purpose was
to compile information that would
be of use in locating students—as
loan recipients—in the event that
ever became necessary.
Lordan added in the memo that
"extracurricular activites of
students have never had any bearing on a student's ability to obtain loans and/or scholarship
funds at the Johns Hopkins
University. Any previous information on extracurricular activities compiled by the Office of
Student loans or elsewhere in the
University will be disposed of and
will have no bearing on financially related matters.
A Coalition press release,
which was also distributed at the
meeting, said that the group "will
be meeting with President Muller
in the next few days to ensure that
this file-keeping does not ever occur again . . .."
The next issue Council discused was a complaint from

Buildings and Grounds Chairman
Jim Finnerty about an incident
which occured at the March 16
rally.
According to Finnerty, Scott
Lippe, a-member of the College
Republicans, "provoked one of
the [Coalition] protestors" during
a counterdemonstration organized by the College Republicans.
Hall, another witness, supported
Finnerty's claims. Finnerty said
that Lippe threatened the protestors at one point.
Not wishing to condemn the
entire organization. Finnerty
suggested that Council pass a
resolution condemning Lippe's
conduct.
Senior Class Representative
Brad Marks opposed this idea.
"It's ridiculous for us to deal with
this," he said. "There should be
a board to deal with [censure of
the actions of individual
students]. We really can't."
Several other Council members
remarked that passage of the type
of resolution requested without
hearing testimony from Lippe
would be improper.
Sophomore Class Representative Susan Land suggested that
discussion be tabled while she and
any other members interested
prepared "a memo to the
Hopkins community." She said
this would prevent Council from
covering the same ground again
at the next meeting.
Land, Hall and others made
various suggestions to the effect
that there should be a limit where
freedom of expression becomes
disruption and should no longer
be permitted on campus.
A variety of issues were also
brought up at Wednesday's Student Council meeting.
Council president-elect Scott
FitzGerald announced that the
Hopkins Shelter Project will continue to function at least until the
end of April. The organization is
composed of student volunteers
who work at a shelter for the
homeless at 2213 Greenmount
Avenue.
An emergency grant from the
city has extended the shelter's
operation, which was to cease on
March 31, and there is a possibility of federal aid after that point,
said FitzGerald.
According to FitzGerald,
"There is a lot of administration
support" for the project, and
there is a possibility that the
group will be made an ongoing
enterprise along the lines of

freshman orientation.
Sophomore Class representative Jonathon Hubbard and FitzGerald both recommended the
project to anyone who might be
interested in participating. Security shuttle van service or student
automobile transportation is
available for both shifts, 6 to 11
p.m. and 11 p.m. to 7a.m.
Interested students can
volunteer to work either shift by
signing up on a list on the door
of the SC office in Levering Hall,
or can call Chris Weininger at
889-8550 for more information,
said FitzGerald.
Senior Class Vice President
Paul Kadri announced that
Hollander Dorm will be attempting to break the world record for
marathon volleyball by playing
for eighty-seven hours. According to Kadri, the Guinness Book
of World Records' value for
longest such game ever played is
now eighty-four hours.
The game will begin at 9 a.m.
on Sunday, April 12 and the
original twelve players in the
game will need to continue
without substitutions in order for
the record to be valid. Players can
drop out without endangering the
attempt "as long as good
volleyball is being played," said
Kadri.

students responding were
freshmen.

that the freshman class plans to
hold an outdoor concert this
spring, although plans are still
tentative and no decision has been
made as to the band.

put forth a binding referendum on

Pepsi will replace Coca-Cola in

continues to profit from apartheid although it claims to have
withdrawn from South Africa last
year.

of protection, or a source of

The Financial File Fiasco
by Paul Genest

Shortly before the publication of our
last issue, we were shocked to learn that
the Office of Student Loans had been
amassing photocopied newspaper clippings concerning the political activities
of certain students. The story broke
when Jessica Reed, a member of the
Coalition for a Free South Africa who
was arrested in the shanty protest of
September 29, noticed Baltimore Sun
clippings in her file several weeks ago.
On March 12, the News-Letter was
able to verify the existence of the clippings, and on March 16, the Coalition
staged a rally which, among other
things, was intended to protest the
presence of extraneous information in
students' financial aid files.
The same day, Vice President of
Business Affairs John J. Lordan announced his decision to purge all financial files of information on "extracurricular activities." In addition, a statement issued by the University that day
emphasized the fact that students have
the legal right to review their files in the
Office of Student Loans.
We applaud Lordan's announcement
and the speed with which it was made.
Decisions concerning the distribution
of financial aid ought to be made

without regard to a recipient's political
beliefs or activities. Certainly then, the
removal of information about those
beliefs and activities is a wise step. It
safeguards students from unfair treatment and enhances the University's image as an institution where the exchange
of opinions is prized.
In recent weeks, certain groups have
suggested that the presence of the
newspaper clippings in financial files
may have been part of a scheme to prevent some students from receiving the
funds necessary for their educations.
But after the events on March 16, we
tend to doubt that explanation.
The candor shown by the Administration in acknowledging the existence of
the materials, the speed with which the
issue was resolved, and the steps taken
to eliminate the threat of. financial
recriminations on politically active
students all suggest that the University
is indeed interested in fair play in its
distribution of financial aid (and probably always has been).
We are pleased with the administration's response to the financial file
fiasco and we hope to see such prudence
in the administration's dealings with
students continue.

been much discussion about the
inevitable disruption of the
University's second most popular
major, I would like to appeal to
the Academic Council, not as an
IS major, but rather as a student
who has been fortunate enough to
have been in one of Dr. David's
classes.
This appeal is being made on
behalf of all of those students,
namely our freshmen and future
Hopkins students, who have not
yet had such an opportunity.
Surely, Dr. David's abilities in
lecture hall are not being called
into question; yet, it is this area
that I would like to emphasize.
Dr. David manages to provide
for his students a stimulating fifty minutes of examination of the
international system. Drawing
ideas from the most reputable
sources, combining them with his
own theories (a reputable source
in itself) and presenting them in
an organized and coherent
fashion, Dr. David succeeds, in
each lecture, in provoking his
students to apply their own
analysis and viewpoint to each
topic.
His ability to link history with
current world affairs is a valuable
aspect of his survey courses. The
occasional wit that he adds to his
lectures is always timely, entertaining, and educating, as it invariably serves to convey an important point. The readings required of the students reflect the
nature of the lectures: they are
relevant, interesting, and
thought-provoking.

the IS department one of the best

research accomplishments. Attention should also be focused on
his abilities as a professor, on his

students in a specific area. Should
that not be the primary duty of a
professor?

beyond fulfilling that duty, as he

has the other requirements which

posters, defaced banners, lectures
disrupted by show-boating
demonstrators of competing
political brand names, and shanties firebombed by louts and pulled to pieces by campus cops, remind me of arguments I had with
my sister when we were children
of a certain age. Both of us would
jam our fingers in our ears and
scream until we were purple to
drown out the other's voice.
Self-blinded armies of competing Thought Police are
clashing all over Hopkins. I'm
thinking of putting up a recruitment poster to see how many applicants would show. Here's the
text:
"Do you wish you could paint
out the anti-Reagan graffiti on the
shanties? Scheme of ways to prevent the publication of posters
you consider anti-feminist?
Chuckle at seeing leftist bulleting
stamped 'KGB Approved"? Do
you nod approvingly when professors espousing theories of intelligence you've decided are
racist are prevented from speaking on. campus?
"Dream of silencing Jerry.
Falwell, Winnie Mandela, Louis
Farrakhan, Susan Brownmiller?
Do you cheer for the burners of
books about evolution, or their
opposite numbers, the Coalitions
to Eliminate Books Judged by the
Coalitions to be Sexist, Racist, or
Violent?
"Most of all do you have What
It Takes: Rigidity and dogmatism
of thought. A preference for
ideology over ideas. A high level
of moral intolerance and selfrighteousness. Above all, you
must have a horror, overarching
as the sky and invisible to
yourself as air, that your beliefs
may not encompass all the truths
in the universe, a horror that if you
entertain any ideas contrary to
that lovingly-contrived idol, your
personal system of thought, the
whole crusty edifice might collapse, leaving you lost in the
ruins.
"If so, then you are perfect raw
material for the Thought Police.
We'll teach you foolproof antithinking and anti-listening techniques. We'll show you how to jam
your fingers in your ears and
howl at lawless and uncertain
thought until the world is filled
with one great uniform Noise of
your own making, and all those
wicked and stupid dissenters are
vaporized!"
If I were to put up that poster,
however, someone would surely
pull it down. When will Hopkins
wake up and remember what is
the Idea of a University?

On 16 March 1987, a variety
of Hopkins students and other individuals gathered on the steps of
Gilman Hall to voice discontent
with CIA interviews on-campus
as well as University tampering
with student loan files. This
demonstration was met be a
counterdemonstration involving
other Hopkins' students.
Unarguably, it is the right of
these groups to express their opinion. Yet, one member of the
counterdemonstration proceeded
to needlessly provoke another individual of the anti-CIA group in
order to provide cause for the termination of the initial gathering.
I witnessed the subsequent ruckus
as the "assaulted" student proceeded to file charges with the
Baltimore City Police.
The placement of material pertaining to student political activities in loan files is a very
serious allegation which merits
concern. Although I do not support the Coalition's argument to
prohibit the CIA from recruiting
on-campus or their views on the
CIA. I very much support their
right to freely express these
views. James Madison posited that the
right to criticize "public
characters and measures" is the
heart of American freedom.
Granted, certain expressions must
be limited in some circumstances
by the weight of greater interests.
This balancing of interests,
however, should not be taken
lightly.
In this sense, the suppression of
dissent contradicts the ideals upon
which this nation was founded as
well as the ideals which I desire
to serve in the Foreign Service.
The suppression of opinions—no
matter how disagreeable or
repulsive—tramples the sentiments espoused in the Declaration of Independence as well as
the Constitution and its Bill of
Rights and repeatedly reaffirmed
in countless other documents and
actions. Democracy rests upon
this diffusion and integration of
diverse notions. Self-appointed
"mindguards"--and their unquestioned acceptance—cause
democratic ideals to wither. This
is especially true in a university
environment in which one purpose of education is to acquire the
tools to critically digest information and then make informed
decisions; that is, an independent
critical spirit.
The use of tactics solely designed to provoke response and thus
curb dissent is deplorable. It
bodes ill for the United States if
the next generation of citizens
cannot rationally discuss opposing ideologies as well as accept
the right to hold and express such
viewpoints rather than hurl personal insults and obscenities or
threaten to "drop bookbags" and
teach lessons to "pansies— (These
words are not mine).
I hold no illusions you will
change, Mr. Lippe, but you
represent that which I abhor—
intelligence constricted by a
closed-mind.

In Perspectives, the News-Letter
will attempt to shed light on issues
ofinterest to the Homewood community by presenting how those
same issues are dealt with on
other campuses.
At Homewood,"The pressure
is building to develop a specific
policy on smoking, which is an
issue under consideration," says
Vice-President for Personnel Programs Robert Wilson in the
March 24th Gazette.
At present, according to
Wilson, there is no smoking
policy in effect in any division of
the University, except the School
of Hygiene and Public Health.
In Canada next week, administrators at the University of
Waterloo will vote on just such a
policy.
Kitchener, Ontario (ISIS)
by Chris Denolm, Imprint
UW's board of governors will
vote April 7 on a controversial
proposal to ban smoking at the
University. If accepted, the proposal- will ban smoking by

January 1, 1988, in 'any University non-residence buildings except in certain suitably ventilated
areas to be decided by management board."
The two-phase proposal, to
begin June 1, will at first proscribe smoking in the following:
"classrooms, amphitheaters,
laboratories, University vehicles,
shared work spaces, offices and
lounges that open onto work
areas,
spaces, reception
restrooms, seminar, conference,
and other meeting rooms."
While it is almost certain the
board of governors will approve
the proposal, there is no telling
what areas the management board
will designate as "suitable" for
smokers.
Smoking is now permitted in
most academic buildings, except
in classrooms, labs, and certain
offices. Students may not smoke
in the E.M.S. Library, but may
do so in the third floor sitting
room in the Arts Library; this will
be discontinued if the smoking
policy is put into effect.
The Villages, because they are
residence buidings, will not be af-

fected by the policy. However,
several complaints concerning
smoking have been received by
the Village 1 office.
A committee set up to consider
the changes to the smoking policy
considered opinions from anyone
interested, but responses came
primarily from faculty and staff,
with a few student contributions.
Director of Personnel Bob Eliot,
who chaired the committee, said
that "most of the response" had
been in favour of a stricter policy.
The University of Waterloo
maintained a smoking policy
since 1967, but it was not revised until August, 1980. The present proposal is the first of its
kind since that date.
According to the 1980 revision,
now in effect, "Smoking areas
may include some coffee,
cafeteria and lounge areas, as
determined by the approp-"Ite
department chairman, hew) or
manager." The present proposal
will do away with this provision,
and will place all authority regarding smoking in the hands of the
management board.

The Flip Side: Where to, U2?
by Phil Gochenour
If you're a child of the 80's and
you haven't heard of U2, you
must've spent your adolescence
in a cave somewhere for the
cultural equivalent thereof. More
likely, however, you have at least
one or two memories for which
U2 is providing the background
music. For me, it's memories of
hot, Tennesee-Williams-Southern
nights spent in abandoned parking lots, with U2's War blaring
out from half-a-dozen car stereos,
providing the stimulus for expressions of adolescent (and some

post-adolescent) angst.
War was the album that
brought U2 to everyone's attention. But before War, there was
Boy (1980), produced by Steve
Lillywhite. U2's first album, it
established them as part of a new
wave of anthem rockers with a
stripped-down, bare-bones
sound. It was the natural
predecessor for War, an album
known for such anthemic songs as
"New Year's Day" and "Sunday, Bloody Sunday." Thus,
with these two albums, it would
seem as if U2 became a definable
entity.

There was another side to U2,
one that was glimpsed on the
album October (1981). Although
still bearing the earmarks of being a Steve Lillywhite production, songs such as "Tomorrow"
and "October" revealed a more
spiritual, sensitive side to U2. In
1984, everyone was anxiously
awaiting the new album to see
how this schizophrenic split
would be resolved. The album
was The Unforgettable Fire, and
it was an even further departure
from the sound of War and Boy
than October had been. The
group dumped Steve Lillywhite

as producer, and picked up the
production team of Eno/Lanois.
The Eno/Lanois team brought
with them a new production
philosophy and a more layered,
processed sound. Keying in on
the expressiveness and range of
Bono's voice, and the clean,
spare sound of the Edge's guitar,
The Unforgettable Fire had the
qualities of a new-wave spiritual.
Fans of the earlier U2 gaped and
wondered what was next—will
that old raw edge of intensity ever
be back?

Durang's Crisp Satire
by Rich Bigelow
Christopher Durang belongs to
a long tradition of playwrights
who use black comedy as a vehicle for social criticism. The current Center Stage production of
The Marriage of Bette and Boo,
which runs through April 12, offers audiences ample opportunity to laugh and squirm. Like those
of his predecessor G.B. Shaw,
Durang's wittiest and truest insights rise out of the hypocrisy
and illusions which organized
religion creates in family life. The
difference is that Durang is a
Catholic Baby Boomer, and the
references he makes to movies
and holidays and the feminine
mystique place his characters and
situations squarely within our experience. His humor is often
blunt and savagely effective. One
scene in the Center Stage production in which a fat priest imitates
frying bacon brought the house
down. The combination of
slapstick, naturalistic dialogue,
and grotesque plot turn the play
into a sort of nightmarish Freudian farce.
The Marriage ofBette and Boo
unfolds as a series of recollections
from the youth of the narrator, an
English Lit. grad student named
Matt Hudlocke (Miles Chaplin).
The play opens with all of the
characters except Matt standing
on a wedding-cake-shaped platform singing a nice, Catholicsounding benediction. Matt
emerges to the side of the stage
and informs the audience that
"just as dreams must be put in
order and perspective in order to
understand them, so must the
endless details of waking life be
ordered and then carefully considered." Bette and Boo are
Matt's parents, and by introducing us to the wedding party he exposes the tragicomic world of his
youth to inspection. The bridal

party is a particularly scary
group. Bette Brennan (Linda
Cook), the bride, a chatty A.A.
Milne reader marrying on the rebound from an unconsummated
affair, has one goal in life: procreation. She has two sisters,
Joan (Alison Bevan), a sharptongued tart whose unfaithful
Greek husband has become a
family joke, and Emily (Mary
Catherine Wright), a sensitive, a
terribly, terribly guilty Catholic
who winds up institutionalized
after failing to become a nun.
These three are dominated by
their mother, Margaret (Theresa
Hughes), a woman who would
rather have her children fail and
live at home than leave the maternal nest. She is seconded in these
efforts by the father of the family, Paul Brennan (Jerry Mayer),
a character who mutters not one
intelligible word in his time on
stage. The groom's party is an
even more sordid assortment of
characters. The groom, Boo
Hudlocke (Stephen Mendillo), a
quiet, thirtyish, thoughtless hunk,
drinks too much. This is a natural
reaction to his father, Karl (John
Carpenter), a viciously foulmouthed misogynist who entertains himself by reminding his
wife Soot (Trinity Thompson)
how stupid she is. The wedding
is performed by a sardonic priest
(I.M. Hobson), and the tale of
marital woe begins.
Characters like the Brennans
and Hudlockes seem more appropriate in soap operas than in
comedies. Part of Durang's talent
as a playwright stems from his
ability to transform their own
sense of seriousness in absurdist
humor. Matt relates the various
episodes which lead to his
parents' divorce in the context of
his own schoolwork, particularly the essays which he always
seems to be writing about
Thomas Hardy. One scene

presents Matt defending a thesis
that Eustacia Vye in The Return
of the Native is neurotic because
her environment forces her to be;
the next scene shows Matt testifying to his father's alcoholism in
divorce court. The disparity between the almost maudlin crises in
his family life and the dignified,
rational analysis he applies to the
lives of the characters in the
novels he studies provides much
comic material. His attitude
towards the Catholic Church
stems as much from the unwillingness of his family to question
harmful doctrines as it does from
the unconcern and irrelevance of
the parish priest. Bette wants to
have lots of children; she and Boo
have the wrong blood type. Bette
gets pregnant, the child dies,
Bette wants another child, Boo
turns to drink. The two logical
solutions to the problem are rejected by the couple for religious
reasons: Boo asks Bette to stop
having kids, but Bette refuses
because she sees no reason why
God can't grant her a miracle and
allow another child to live the
way Matt did. Bette goes through
five pregnancies and four
stillbirths. The couple rejects
divorce until after the fifth
pregnancy because it is against
Catholic doctrine. The whole
family goes on a marriage retreat
at one point, to be told by the
priest that he cannot do anything
for them because "A husband and
wife are stuck together." The
play is punctuated by scenes in
the hospital waiting room when
the various stillborn blue or pink
bundles are thrown on the stage
and everyone has to decide what
to do with them. Matt sees things
in a grotesque light, yet his world
is both humorous and poignant.
The Center Stage production
holds up to the challenge to be
both very funny and retain the
sense of familiarity Durang's

situations evoke from the audience. Director Richard Hamburger elicits crisp, substantial
performancesfrom everyone in
his tight professional ensemble.
Special mention should be made
of Linda Cook's performance as
Bette, a role which demands both
emotional virtuosity and an ability
to play stupid well. The set design
and musical score enhance the
macabre effect of the humor by
placing the actors' naturalistic
character studies in the context of
a cartoon-like world, with a set
and sounds that belong on a
"Peanuts" T.V. special. The expressionistic production values
set well with the kind of quirky
narrative Durang uses, somewhat
reminiscent of Tennessee
Williams.
The more obvious Williams
parallel, Matt's role as a narrator

in a memory play, raises the
question of the relationship between comedy and drama. The
gross quality of the lives of
Durang's characters as viewed in
retrospect by Matt turn the play
into a sort of parody of The Glass
Menagerie. Because the play does
not appear to take itself seriously. Durang is able to take aim at
the cynicism, passivity, and
credulity of modern life in a way
in which something calling itself
a drama could not. His willingness to caricature those who
refuse to take ir -iportant life decisions for themselves and then set
out to prove to the world they
really are martyrs transcends
most serious drama. Center Stage
has mounted a fine production of
a literate play by a major
American playwright. It deserves
to be seen.

by Michael Frabowitz
It all began with a telephone call
from a New York newspaper
reporter, asking all kinds of
strange questions. Then I started
to suspect something was up,
reminisces Dr. Christian B. Anfinsen, Professor of Biology. The
next morning the Nobel committee called from Stockholm and his
suspicions were confirmed. He
has been awarded the Nobel Prize
for Chemistry in 1972. Dr. Anfinsen currently teaches a section
of Molecular and Cellular
Biology, and conducts research in
collaboration with Dr. L. Brand,
also of the Biology department.
This current research involves
replacing Tryptophan, an amino
acid in a long protein chain, with
another amino acid, or modifying
the environment of the tryptophan
residue, and conducting flourescent analysis on the protein.
Dr. Anfinsen began his
pioneering research in 1957 at the
National Institutes of Health in
Bethesda, Maryland. This period
in time was an extremely productive one for NIH, due to the
Korean War, and subsequently,
the Vietnam War. "The NIH was
able to commission bright M.D.'s
in med. schools before they were
drafted," Dr. Anfinsen says.
This led to a conducive atmosphere for research, with the
best people in medicine taking
part. Additionally, since the NIH
is a government research institution, there is no need to apply for
research grants. There was also
no teaching obligation, because
NIH is totally dedicated to
research.

Laxers Shocked 9-7 By Cavaliers At Home
by Christopher Szeles
Johns Hopkins (3-2) has just
strolled past the halfway mark of
their lacrosse regular season, but
in the words of Coach Don Zimmerman, "We haven't proven
anything yet."
After two superb games in
which Hopkins dominated each
quarter, Zimmerman was upset
by a talented Virginia squad. The
games against Washington College and Princeton were convincing exhibitions for th! Jays, but
the contests were not real tests for
Hopkins.
This season it appears that
Princeton will have a tough time
improving on their win production of last year, a lone victory.
And Division III Washington is
not the Hobart power that managed a Syracuse upset last year.
A peculiar event happened to
the pesky Jays against Virginia.
Even more unusual than a loss on
Hopkins' magic carpet was the
shocking final score, 9-7. The
Cavaliers won by two goals.
Entering the Virginia contest,
the Zimmerman dynasty had a
grand total of four losses (with 40
wins) spanning four seasons but
had never lost a decision by more
than one score.
Zimmerman labelled the loss to
Virginia "a team effort" and
added, "They all played poorly.
We're still trying to play our best
lacrosse."
The Blue Jays, however, are
not panicking yet. With the expanded NCAA lacrosse tournament field now set at twelve,
Hopkins would most likely struggle into the tournament with a
.500 record, using their strength
of schedule as a crutch.
It wouldn't be surprising if all
of the 1987 Blue Jays Division I
opponents except Princeton make
the tournament.
Hopkins will not have another
easy game this season and must
face North Carolina, Army,
Maryland, Navy, and Towson

HOPKINS 10, RUTGERS 7
Sat., March 14
Johns Hopkins found itself
squeezed into a must-win situation early in the season. The Blue
Jays were coming off a slow-start
15-14 loss at Syracuse and were
playing without Brian Wood and
Greg Gunning.
Rutgers had lost to Navy, 7-6,
in recent action, when the Midshipmen staged a late rally. The
Scarlet Knights were slain in
another fourth-quarter surge, as

Hopkins shrugged off a sleepy
start and notched the last five
scores of the contest to capture a
10-7 victory.
Rutgers held a 7-5 lead in the
final period behind the scoring of
Bill Herger and Ed Trabulsky.
Herger, a junior midfielder, netted the first two goals of the
game. Trabulsky added a pair in

Unleashing a blistering offensive attack, Johns Hopkins tamed the Princeton Tigers, 21-6,
before 6,500 at Homewood Field.
The mighty Blue Jays, who put
on a passing and stickwork clinic,
won their third consecutive game,
building a 10-3 halftime lead.
Hopkins outshot the Ivy League
felines, 60-32, and won 20 of the
31 faceoffs.
"Hopkins has so much talent,"
said Princeton coach Jerry
Schmidt, a former All-America
attackman with the Jays. "They
move the ball so well, especially
inside, it was like they were on
extra-man all afternoon."
The Blue Jays put 38 of its 60
shots on goal, hit the post with
four other rockets and scored
three extra-man goals in six opportunities. John Wright, the
sophomore Tiger goalie, was
outstanding in the goal, making
17 saves. He, perhaps, saved the
rambunctious Hopkins band from
performing a concert.
The Hopkins defense was so
strong that it did not commit a
foul for the first 44 minutes and
12 seconds, allowed only one
extra-man score, and continually
checked the ball out of the black
and blued Princeton players'
sticks.
Once again, Hopkins bolted out
of the starting blocks and captured a 4-0 lead. The Jays never
looked back.
Greg Kelly started the scoring
action by bouncing in a goal, using an assist from John Ciccarone
at 1:17. Craig Bubier found a
missed shot behind the left side of
the Princeton net and delivered it
for a tally from 5 yards away with
2:11 gone in the contest.
Ciccarone made it 3-0, when
he bounced in a goal from the
right side off a Brendan Kelly
pass at 6:12.
Bubier gave an assist to Scott
Marr, as Bubier's blast found the
net again at the 9:55 mark of the
sprint for a 4-0 advantage. "I was
generally pleased with our efContinued on Page 25

The Jays were beaten on
groundballs and faceoffs. Then
the Jays were beaten on the
scoreboard on their home turf
before a near-sellout crowd of
6,000.
"I still don't know why we
played so poorly today," said
coach Don Zimmerman, shaking
his head in disgust. "We just
weren't ready to play the game.
Our timing was off, and we didn't
hustle."
The Cavaliers held a 53-41
edge in groundballs, which simply means they outhustled the Blue
Jays. Virginia had not beaten
Johns Hopkins since 1980, 12-9,
and had not won at Homewood
Field since 1971, 9-8.
The Blue Jays were out of sync
offensively and several times
missed cutters for potential goals.
Early in the third period Mike
Morrill collided with teammate
Dave Pietramala at midfield. And
no one was even checking them.
The Cavaliers' freshman
goaltender Stew Ridgley from St.
Paul's School added to the Jays'
frustration and finished with 16
saves. Virginia fans did not notice
the absence of injured Peter
Sheehan, the nation's best goalie
in 1986.
"Lacrosse is a game of hustling, and the team that gobbles up
those loose balls usually wins,"
said Zimmerman."We kept giving them second and third opportunities, and you can't give a team
the caliber of Virginia that many
chances. When you have five or
six people standing around on offense at one time, it cuts down on
your scoring opportunities. We
should be doubling what we
scored today. I'm extremely
disappointed in our offense."

by Seth Goodman
Welcome back, my friends. I
know all of you were lying there
on the beach, wondering what
was coming up in BIA. Well, I
don't blame you cause I was kind
of curious myself. With only a
few events left, point totals are
due, and you will see them next
week.
The lacrosse season is in full
swing, and will continue through
next week. The top teams, as
always, should be preparing for
the playoffs. As I was once again
reminded in that crazy NCAA
tournament, just about anything
can happen, and usually does
Don't be a spectator, get out there
and do it.
The softball season gets underway on Monday, April 6. As the
final seasonal sport, it provides
the last chance to make up a large
deficit in the standings. And even
if you're not a frontrunner, why
not just go out and have a good
time. Play a little ball, catch a few

rays. What else is there? Signup
your team by 4PM on Friday.
Call Cary at 243-7817 for additional info.
The remainder of the season
has the Track & Field meet the
weekend of April 11-12, and the
Doubles Tennis Tourney on April
18-19. As well, I hate to be the
one to spread vicious rumors, but
I heard through the grapevine that
a contract is being negotiatied
which would make the contraversial floor hockey tournament a
reality. The Olympic Planning
Committee said that if our
endeavor is a success, floor
hockey just might be an exhibition sport in 1990. Imagine that.
On a serious note, a signup
sheet is now in the BIA mailbox
in the AC office for any
freshman, sophomore,junior, or
senior who just isn't quite going
to make it, who is interested in
becoming a part of the Intramural
Board. The deadline for signing
up is April 17. Those persons will
then be contacted to arrange an
interview.
